content:
The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for increased disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, software for filing reports, limits on soft money of national political party committees, contribution limits, and miscellaneous provisions such as prohibiting solicitation of political party soft money in Federal buildings and updating penalty amounts. The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes provisions for increased disclosure reports, reporting by national political party committees, electronic disclosure, public access to broadcasting records, software for filing reports, limits on soft money of national political party committees, contribution limits, and miscellaneous provisions such as prohibiting solicitation of political party soft money in Federal buildings and updating penalty amounts. Additionally, there are updates on penalty amounts and the filing of Senate reports with the Federal Election Commission under Title I - Disclosure. The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" includes amendments to monthly and quarterly reporting requirements for principal campaign committees under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Monthly reports are to be filed by the 20th day after the last day of the month, except for November and December, with a year-end report due by January 31 of the following year. Quarterly reports must be filed by the 15th day after the last day of each calendar quarter. The "Open and Accountable Campaign Financing Act of 2001" amends reporting requirements for principal campaign committees under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. Monthly reports are due by the 20th day after the last day of the month, except for November and December, with a year-end report due by January 31 of the following year. Quarterly reports must be filed by the 15th day after the last day of each calendar quarter. The Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require monthly reports instead of quarterly reports. Additionally, Section 309 of the Act is amended to replace "calendar quarter" with "month". SEC. 102 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to require national political party committees to report all receipts and disbursements during the reporting period, with itemization for amounts exceeding $200 from any person in a calendar year. SEC. 103 calls for increased electronic disclosure. SEC. 103 calls for increased electronic disclosure of campaign finance reports, making the information available on the internet and publicly accessible within 24 hours of submission to the Commission. SEC. 104 addresses public access to broadcasting records. Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 requires licensees to maintain and make public a complete record of requests to purchase broadcast time related to political matters of national importance. This includes requests made by or on behalf of candidates for public office or messages on national legislative issues. The record must include information on whether the broadcast time request was accepted or rejected. The record maintained under Section 315 of the Communications Act of 1934 includes details such as whether the broadcast time request was accepted, the rate charged, date and time of airing, class of time purchased, candidate's name and office sought, and committee information. The information required for political advertising requests includes details like the candidate's name, authorized committee, treasurer, purchaser's name, contact person's details, and executive committee/board members. This information must be placed in a political file promptly and retained by the licensee for a minimum of 2 years. SEC. 105 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act to require the development and use of software for filing reports. The Commission must provide this software at no cost to those required to file reports. SEC. 201 imposes limits on soft money contributions of national political party committees under Title III of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. SEC. 202. JUDICIAL REVIEW. The section imposes limits on donations, gifts, or transfers of funds to political party committees. A person cannot exceed $60,000 in disbursements in a calendar year. Amounts are adjusted annually based on the price index. Expedited Review allows certain entities to challenge the constitutionality of section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act in the US District Court for the District of Columbia. Appeals can be made directly to the Supreme Court. The courts are required to prioritize and expedite these cases. The provision allows for expedited consideration of challenges to section 324 of the Federal Election Campaign Act in the District Court for the District of Columbia and the Supreme Court. Enforcement of section 324 is stayed until a final decision is made by the Supreme Court, and the provision applies to actions filed within 30 days of the Act's effective date. SEC. 203. INCREASE IN CONTRIBUTION LIMITS. Increase in contribution limits under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971, including raising individual and political committee limits to $3,000, $60,000, and $15,000 respectively, and multicandidate limits to $7,500. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits, including raising individual and political committee limits to $7,500 and multicandidate limits to $15,000. Additionally, the Act is amended to include a provision for national committees of political parties exceeding $15,000 in contributions to candidates and their authorized committees for Federal office elections. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits, with limitations under subsections (a) and (h) remaining in effect for a 2-year period after being increased. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase contribution limits for Senate candidate contribution limits for national party committees and senatorial campaign committees. The amendments made by this section apply to calendar years beginning after December 31, 2001, with specific provisions for subsections (b) and (d) in calendar year 1974 and subsections (a) and (h) in calendar year 2001. The amendment for Senate candidate contribution limits will apply to calendar years after December 31, 2002. TITLE III--MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS

SEC. 301. PROHIBITION OF SOLICITATION OF POLITICAL PARTY SOFT MONEY IN FEDERAL BUILDINGS.

Amends Section 607 of title 18, United States Code, to define "contribution" and prohibit solicitation of political party soft money in federal buildings. Amends Section 602(a)(4) to include the prohibition of donations. SEC. 302. UPDATE OF PENALTY AMOUNTS. Amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to adjust dollar amounts for inflation after 2001. SEC. 303. FILING OF SENATE REPORTS WITH THE FEDERAL ELECTION COMMISSION. SEC. 303 amends the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to specify that all required filings shall be submitted to the Commission. Conforming amendments are made to other sections regarding filing requirements.
